V-71849.desc: Discretionary access control is weakened if a user or group has access permissions to system files and directories greater than the default.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the file permissions, ownership, and group membership of system files and commands match the vendor values.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the default file permissions, ownership, and group membership of system files and commands with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# for i in `rpm -Va | egrep -i '^\.[M|U|G|.]{8}' | cut -d " " -f4,5`;do for j in `rpm -qf $i`;do rpm -ql $j --dump | cut -d " " -f1,5,6,7 | grep $i;done;done{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/var/log/gdm 040755 root root{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf 0100640 root root{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/usr/bin/passwd 0104755 root root{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}For each file returned, verify the current permissions, ownership, and group membership:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -la <filename>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-------. 1 root root 133 Jan 11 13:25 /etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file is more permissive than the default permissions, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file is not owned by the default owner and is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO), this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file is not a member of the default group and is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO), this is a finding.
descs.fix: Run the following command to determine which package owns the file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rpm -qf <filename>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Reset the user and group ownership of files within a package with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#rpm --setugids <packagename>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Reset the permissions of files within a package with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#rpm --setperms <packagename>

V-71855.desc: Without cryptographic integrity protections, system command and files can be altered by unauthorized users without detection.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Cryptographic mechanisms used for protecting the integrity of information include, for example, signed hash functions using asymmetric cryptography enabling distribution of the public key to verify the hash information while maintaining the confidentiality of the key used to generate the hash.

descs.check: Verify the cryptographic hash of system files and commands match the vendor values.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the cryptographic hash of system files and commands with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: System configuration files (indicated by a "c" in the second column) are expected to change over time. Unusual modifications should be investigated through the system audit log.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rpm -Va --noconfig | grep '^..5'{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is any output from the command for system files or binaries, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Run the following command to determine which package owns the file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rpm -qf <filename>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The package can be reinstalled from a yum repository using the command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sudo yum reinstall <packagename>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Alternatively, the package can be reinstalled from trusted media using the command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sudo rpm -Uvh <packagename>

V-71891.desc: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Regardless of where the session lock is determined and implemented, once invoked, the session lock must remain in place until the user reauthenticates. No other activity aside from reauthentication must unlock the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system enables a user's session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures. The screen program must be installed to lock sessions on the console.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If the system does not have GNOME installed, this requirement is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if the screen lock is enabled with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i lock-enabled /etc/dconf/db/local.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}lock-enabled=true{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "lock-enabled" setting is missing or is not set to "true", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to enable a user's session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following example:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Edit the "[org/gnome/desktop/screensaver]" section of the database file and add or update the following lines:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# Set this to true to lock the screen when the screensaver activates{{{{newlineHERE}}}}lock-enabled=true{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Update the system databases:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# dconf update{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.

V-71893.desc: A session time-out lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not log out because of the temporary nature of the absence. Rather than relying on the user to manually lock their operating system session prior to vacating the vicinity, operating systems need to be able to identify when a user's session has idled and take action to initiate the session lock.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined and/or controlled.

descs.check: Verify the operating system initiates a screensaver after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces. The screen program must be installed to lock sessions on the console.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If the system does not have GNOME installed, this requirement is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if GNOME is configured to display a screensaver after a 15 minute delay with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i idle-delay /etc/dconf/db/local.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}idle-delay=uint32 900{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "idle-delay" setting is missing or is not set to "900" or less, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to initiate a screensaver after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Edit /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver and add or update the following lines:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}[org/gnome/desktop/session]{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# Set the lock time out to 900 seconds before the session is considered idle{{{{newlineHERE}}}}idle-delay=uint32 900{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}You must include the "uint32" along with the integer key values as shown.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Update the system databases:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# dconf update{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.

descs.fix: Configure the operating system to initiate a session lock for graphical user interfaces when a screensaver is activated.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-screensaver{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the setting to enable session locking when a screensaver is activated:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}[org/gnome/desktop/screensaver]{{{{newlineHERE}}}}lock-delay=uint32 5{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The "uint32" must be included along with the integer key values as shown.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Update the system databases:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# dconf update{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Users must log out and back in again before the system-wide settings take effect.

descs.check: Verify the PAM system service is configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords. The strength of encryption that must be used to hash passwords for all accounts is SHA512.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the system is configured to create SHA512 hashed passwords with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep password /etc/pam.d/system-auth /etc/pam.d/password-auth{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Outcome should look like following:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/etc/pam.d/system-auth-ac:password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/etc/pam.d/password-auth:password sufficient pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" configuration files allow for password hashes other than SHA512 to be used, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to store only SHA512 encrypted representations of passwords.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/password-auth":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: Manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authconfig" program. The "authconfig" program should not be used to update the configurations listed in this requirement.

descs.check: Verify the operating system enforces 24 hours/1 day as the minimum password lifetime for new user accounts.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the value of "PASS_MIN_DAYS" in "/etc/login.defs" with the following command: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i pass_min_days /etc/login.defs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}PASS_MIN_DAYS 1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "PASS_MIN_DAYS" parameter value is not "1" or greater, or is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to enforce 24 hours/1 day as the minimum password lifetime.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}PASS_MIN_DAYS 1

descs.check: Check whether the minimum time period between password changes for each user account is one day or greater.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# awk -F: '$4 < 1 {print $1 " " $4}' /etc/shadow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any results are returned that are not associated with a system account, this is a finding.

descs.check: Check whether the maximum time period for existing passwords is restricted to 60 days.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# awk -F: '$5 > 60 {print $1 " " $5}' /etc/shadow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any results are returned that are not associated with a system account, this is a finding.

descs.check: Verify the operating system prohibits password reuse for a minimum of five generations.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the value of the "remember" argument in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i remember /etc/pam.d/system-auth /etc/pam.d/password-auth{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}password requisite pam_pwhistory.so use_authtok remember=5 retry=3{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the line containing the "pam_pwhistory.so" line does not have the "remember" module argument set, is commented out, or the value of the "remember" module argument is set to less than "5", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}password requisite pam_pwhistory.so use_authtok remember=5 retry=3{{{{newlineHERE}}}} {{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: Manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authconfig" program. The "authconfig" program should not be used to update the configurations listed in this requirement.

V-71935.desc: The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to exponentially increase the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

descs.fix: Configure operating system to enforce a minimum 15-character password length.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}minlen = 15

The "authconfig" program should not be used to update the configurations listed in this requirement.

descs.check: To determine how the SSH daemon's "PermitEmptyPasswords" option is set, run the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i PermitEmptyPasswords /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}PermitEmptyPasswords no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If no line, a commented line, or a line indicating the value "no" is returned, the required value is set.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the required value is not set, this is a finding.
descs.fix: To explicitly disallow remote logon from accounts with empty passwords, add or correct the following line in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}PermitEmptyPasswords no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect. V-71951.desc: Configuring the operating system to implement organization-wide security implementation guides and security checklists verifies compliance with federal standards and establishes a common security baseline across DoD that reflects the most restrictive security posture consistent with operational requirements.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Configuration settings are the set of parameters that can be changed in hardware, software, or firmware components of the system that affect the security posture and/or functionality of the system. Security-related parameters are those parameters impacting the security state of the system, including the parameters required to satisfy other security control requirements. Security-related parameters include, for example, registry settings; account, file, and directory permission settings; and settings for functions, ports, protocols, services, and remote connections.

descs.check: Verify the operating system enforces a delay of at least four seconds between console logon prompts following a failed logon attempt.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the value of the "fail_delay" parameter in the "/etc/login.defs" file with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i fail_delay /etc/login.defs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}FAIL_DELAY 4{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value of "FAIL_DELAY" is not set to "4" or greater, or the line is commented out, this is a finding.

descs.check: For systems that use UEFI, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}For systems that are running RHEL 7.2 or newer, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if an encrypted root password is set. On systems that use a BIOS, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i password_pbkdf2 /boot/grub2/grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}password_pbkdf2 [superusers-account] [password-hash]{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the root password entry does not begin with "password_pbkdf2", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "superusers-account" is not set to "root", this is a finding.

V-71965.desc: To assure accountability and prevent unauthenticated access, organizational users must be identified and authenticated to prevent potential misuse and compromise of the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Organizational users include organizational employees or individuals the organization deems to have equivalent status of employees (e.g., contractors). Organizational users (and processes acting on behalf of users) must be uniquely identified and authenticated to all accesses, except for the following:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}1) Accesses explicitly identified and documented by the organization. Organizations document specific user actions that can be performed on the information system without identification or authentication; {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}and{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}2) Accesses that occur through authorized use of group authenticators without individual authentication. Organizations may require unique identification of individuals in group accounts (e.g., shared privilege accounts) or for detailed accountability of individual activity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system requires multifactor authentication to uniquely identify organizational users using multifactor authentication.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if smartcard authentication is enforced on the system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# authconfig --test | grep "pam_pkcs11 is enabled"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If no results are returned, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# authconfig --test | grep "smartcard removal action"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "smartcard removal action" is blank, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# authconfig --test | grep "smartcard module"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "smartcard module" is blank, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to require individuals to be authenticated with a multifactor authenticator.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Enable smartcard logons with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# authconfig --enablesmartcard --smartcardaction=0 --update{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# authconfig --enablerequiresmartcard -update{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Modify the "/etc/pam_pkcs11/pkcs11_eventmgr.conf" file to uncomment the following line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#/usr/X11R6/bin/xscreensaver-command -lock{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Modify the "/etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf" file to use the cackey module if required.

V-71967.desc: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The rsh-server service provides an unencrypted remote access service that does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session and has very weak authentication.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a privileged user were to log on using this service, the privileged user password could be compromised.

descs.check: Check to see if the rsh-server package is installed with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed rsh-server{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the rsh-server package is installed, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to disable non-essential capabilities by removing the rsh-server package from the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum remove rsh-server

descs.check: The NIS service provides an unencrypted authentication service that does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if the "ypserve" package is installed with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed ypserv{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "ypserv" package is installed, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to disable non-essential capabilities by removing the "ypserv" package from the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum remove ypserv

V-71971.desc: Preventing non-privileged users from executing privileged functions mitigates the risk that unauthorized individuals or processes may gain unnecessary access to information or privileges.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Privileged functions include, for example, establishing accounts, performing system integrity checks, or administering cryptographic key management activities. Non-privileged users are individuals who do not possess appropriate authorizations. Circumventing intrusion detection and prevention mechanisms or malicious code protection mechanisms are examples of privileged functions that require protection from non-privileged users.

descs.check: If an HBSS or HIPS is active on the system, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the operating system prevents non-privileged users from executing privileged functions to include disabling, circumventing, or altering implemented security safeguards/countermeasures.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Get a list of authorized users (other than System Administrator and guest accounts) for the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the list against the system by using the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# semanage login -l | more{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Login Name SELinux User MLS/MCS Range Service{{{{newlineHERE}}}}__default__ user_u s0-s0:c0.c1023 *{{{{newlineHERE}}}}root unconfined_u s0-s0:c0.c1023 *{{{{newlineHERE}}}}system_u system_u s0-s0:c0.c1023 *{{{{newlineHERE}}}}joe staff_u s0-s0:c0.c1023 *{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}All administrators must be mapped to the "sysadm_u", "staff_u", or an appropriately tailored confined role as defined by the organization.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}All authorized non-administrative users must be mapped to the "user_u" role. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If they are not mapped in this way, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions to include disabling, circumventing, or altering implemented security safeguards/countermeasures.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to map a new user to the "sysadm_u" role: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#semanage login -a -s sysadm_u <username>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to map an existing user to the "sysadm_u" role:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#semanage login -m -s sysadm_u <username>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to map a new user to the "staff_u" role:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#semanage login -a -s staff_u <username>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to map an existing user to the "staff_u" role:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#semanage login -m -s staff_u <username>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to map a new user to the "user_u" role:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# semanage login -a -s user_u <username>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to map an existing user to the "user_u" role:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# semanage login -m -s user_u <username>

V-71973.desc: Unauthorized changes to the baseline configuration could make the system vulnerable to various attacks or allow unauthorized access to the operating system. Changes to operating system configurations can have unintended side effects, some of which may be relevant to security.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Detecting such changes and providing an automated response can help avoid unintended, negative consequences that could ultimately affect the security state of the operating system. The operating system's Information Management Officer (IMO)/Information System Security Officer (ISSO) and System Administrators (SAs) must be notified via email and/or monitoring system trap when there is an unauthorized modification of a configuration item.

descs.check: Verify the operating system routinely checks the baseline configuration for unauthorized changes.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: A file integrity tool other than Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment (AIDE) may be used, but the tool must be executed at least once per week.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if AIDE is installed on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is not installed, ask the SA how file integrity checks are performed on the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the presence of a cron job running daily or weekly on the system that executes AIDE daily to scan for changes to the system baseline. The command used in the example will use a daily occurrence.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the cron directories for a script file controlling the execution of the file integrity application. For example, if AIDE is installed on the system, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/cron.* | grep aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 29 Nov 22 2015 aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep aide /etc/crontab /var/spool/cron/root{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/etc/crontab: 30 04 * * * /root/aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/var/spool/cron/root: 30 04 * * * /root/aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file integrity application does not exist, or a script file controlling the execution of the file integrity application does not exist, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the file integrity tool to run automatically on the system at least weekly. The following example output is generic. It will set cron to run AIDE daily, but other file integrity tools may be used: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# more /etc/cron.daily/aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#!/bin/bash{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/usr/sbin/aide --check | /bin/mail -s "$HOSTNAME - Daily aide integrity check run" root@sysname.mil

V-71975.desc: Unauthorized changes to the baseline configuration could make the system vulnerable to various attacks or allow unauthorized access to the operating system. Changes to operating system configurations can have unintended side effects, some of which may be relevant to security.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Detecting such changes and providing an automated response can help avoid unintended, negative consequences that could ultimately affect the security state of the operating system. The operating system's Information Management Officer (IMO)/Information System Security Officer (ISSO) and System Administrators (SAs) must be notified via email and/or monitoring system trap when there is an unauthorized modification of a configuration item.

descs.check: Verify the operating system notifies designated personnel if baseline configurations are changed in an unauthorized manner.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: A file integrity tool other than Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment (AIDE) may be used, but the tool must be executed and notify specified individuals via email or an alert.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if AIDE is installed on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is not installed, ask the SA how file integrity checks are performed on the system. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the presence of a cron job running routinely on the system that executes AIDE to scan for changes to the system baseline. The commands used in the example will use a daily occurrence.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the cron directories for a "crontab" script file controlling the execution of the file integrity application. For example, if AIDE is installed on the system, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/cron.* | grep aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 32 Jul 1 2011 aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep aide /etc/crontab /var/spool/cron/root{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/etc/crontab: 30 04 * * * /root/aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/var/spool/cron/root: 30 04 * * * /root/aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}AIDE does not have a configuration that will send a notification, so the cron job uses the mail application on the system to email the results of the file integrity run as in the following example:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# more /etc/cron.daily/aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#!/bin/bash{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/usr/sbin/aide --check | /bin/mail -s "$HOSTNAME - Daily aide integrity check run" root@sysname.mil{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file integrity application does not notify designated personnel of changes, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to notify designated personnel if baseline configurations are changed in an unauthorized manner. The AIDE tool can be configured to email designated personnel with the use of the cron system. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The following example output is generic. It will set cron to run AIDE daily and to send email at the completion of the analysis. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# more /etc/cron.daily/aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/usr/sbin/aide --check | /bin/mail -s "$HOSTNAME - Daily aide integrity check run" root@sysname.mil

V-71977.desc: Changes to any software components can have significant effects on the overall security of the operating system. This requirement ensures the software has not been tampered with and that it has been provided by a trusted vendor.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Accordingly, patches, service packs, device drivers, or operating system components must be signed with a certificate recognized and approved by the organization.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verifying the authenticity of the software prior to installation validates the integrity of the patch or upgrade received from a vendor. This verifies the software has not been tampered with and that it has been provided by a trusted vendor. Self-signed certificates are disallowed by this requirement. The operating system should not have to verify the software again. This requirement does not mandate DoD certificates for this purpose; however, the certificate used to verify the software must be from an approved CA.

descs.check: Verify the operating system prevents the installation of patches, service packs, device drivers, or operating system components from a repository without verification that they have been digitally signed using a certificate that is recognized and approved by the organization.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that yum verifies the signature of packages from a repository prior to install with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep gpgcheck /etc/yum.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}gpgcheck=1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "gpgcheck" is not set to "1", or if options are missing or commented out, ask the System Administrator how the certificates for patches and other operating system components are verified. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no process to validate certificates that is approved by the organization, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to verify the signature of packages from a repository prior to install by setting the following option in the "/etc/yum.conf" file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}gpgcheck=1

V-71979.desc: Changes to any software components can have significant effects on the overall security of the operating system. This requirement ensures the software has not been tampered with and that it has been provided by a trusted vendor.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Accordingly, patches, service packs, device drivers, or operating system components must be signed with a certificate recognized and approved by the organization.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verifying the authenticity of the software prior to installation validates the integrity of the patch or upgrade received from a vendor. This verifies the software has not been tampered with and that it has been provided by a trusted vendor. Self-signed certificates are disallowed by this requirement. The operating system should not have to verify the software again. This requirement does not mandate DoD certificates for this purpose; however, the certificate used to verify the software must be from an approved CA.

descs.check: Verify the operating system prevents the installation of patches, service packs, device drivers, or operating system components of local packages without verification that they have been digitally signed using a certificate that is recognized and approved by the organization.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that yum verifies the signature of local packages prior to install with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep localpkg_gpgcheck /etc/yum.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}localpkg_gpgcheck=1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "localpkg_gpgcheck" is not set to "1", or if options are missing or commented out, ask the System Administrator how the signatures of local packages and other operating system components are verified. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no process to validate the signatures of local packages that is approved by the organization, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to verify the signature of local packages prior to install by setting the following option in the "/etc/yum.conf" file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}localpkg_gpgcheck=1

V-71983.desc: USB mass storage permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: If there is an HBSS with a Device Control Module and a Data Loss Prevention mechanism, this requirement is not applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the operating system disables the ability to load the USB Storage kernel module.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -r usb-storage /etc/modprobe.d/* | grep -i "/bin/true" | grep -v "^#"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}install usb-storage /bin/true{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the command does not return any output, or the line is commented out, and use of USB Storage is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO) as an operational requirement, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the operating system disables the ability to use USB mass storage devices.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if USB mass storage is disabled with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep usb-storage /etc/modprobe.d/* | grep -i "blacklist" | grep -v "^#"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}blacklist usb-storage{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the command does not return any output or the output is not "blacklist usb-storage", and use of USB storage devices is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO) as an operational requirement, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use the USB Storage kernel module.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Create a file under "/etc/modprobe.d" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# touch /etc/modprobe.d/usb-storage.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line to the created file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}install usb-storage /bin/true{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use USB mass storage devices.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add or update the line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}blacklist usb-storage

V-71985.desc: Automatically mounting file systems permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system disables the ability to automount devices.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if automounter service is active with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl status autofs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}autofs.service - Automounts filesystems on demand{{{{newlineHERE}}}} Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/autofs.service; disabled){{{{newlineHERE}}}} Active: inactive (dead){{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "autofs" status is set to "active" and is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO) as an operational requirement, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to disable the ability to automount devices.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Turn off the automount service with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl stop autofs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl disable autofs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "autofs" is required for Network File System (NFS), it must be documented with the ISSO.

descs.check: Verify the operating system removes all software components after updated versions have been installed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check if yum is configured to remove unneeded packages with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i clean_requirements_on_remove /etc/yum.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}clean_requirements_on_remove=1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "clean_requirements_on_remove" is not set to "1", "True", or "yes", or is not set in "/etc/yum.conf", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to remove all software components after updated versions have been installed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the "clean_requirements_on_remove" option to "1" in the "/etc/yum.conf" file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}clean_requirements_on_remove=1

V-71989.desc: Without verification of the security functions, security functions may not operate correctly and the failure may go unnoticed. Security function is defined as the hardware, software, and/or firmware of the information system responsible for enforcing the system security policy and supporting the isolation of code and data on which the protection is based. Security functionality includes, but is not limited to, establishing system accounts, configuring access authorizations (i.e., permissions, privileges), setting events to be audited, and setting intrusion detection parameters.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement applies to operating systems performing security function verification/testing and/or systems and environments that require this functionality.

descs.check: If an HBSS or HIPS is active on the system, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the operating system verifies correct operation of all security functions.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check if "SELinux" is active and in "Enforcing" mode with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# getenforce{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Enforcing{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "SELinux" is not active and not in "Enforcing" mode, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to verify correct operation of all security functions.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the "SELinux" status and the "Enforcing" mode by modifying the "/etc/selinux/config" file to have the following line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}SELINUX=enforcing{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}A reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

V-71991.desc: Without verification of the security functions, security functions may not operate correctly and the failure may go unnoticed. Security function is defined as the hardware, software, and/or firmware of the information system responsible for enforcing the system security policy and supporting the isolation of code and data on which the protection is based. Security functionality includes, but is not limited to, establishing system accounts, configuring access authorizations (i.e., permissions, privileges), setting events to be audited, and setting intrusion detection parameters.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement applies to operating systems performing security function verification/testing and/or systems and environments that require this functionality.

descs.check: If an HBSS or HIPS is active on the system, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the operating system verifies correct operation of all security functions.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check if "SELinux" is active and is enforcing the targeted policy with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sestatus{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}SELinux status: enabled{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}SELinuxfs mount: /selinux{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}SELinux root directory: /etc/selinux{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Loaded policy name: targeted{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current mode: enforcing{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Mode from config file: enforcing{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Policy MLS status: enabled{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Policy deny_unknown status: allowed{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Max kernel policy version: 28{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "Loaded policy name" is not set to "targeted", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify that the /etc/selinux/config file is configured to the "SELINUXTYPE" to "targeted":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i "selinuxtype" /etc/selinux/config | grep -v '^#'{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}SELINUXTYPE = targeted{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If no results are returned or "SELINUXTYPE" is not set to "targeted", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to verify correct operation of all security functions.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the "SELinuxtype" to the "targeted" policy by modifying the "/etc/selinux/config" file to have the following line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}SELINUXTYPE=targeted{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}A reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

descs.check: Verify the operating system is not configured to reboot the system when Ctrl-Alt-Delete is pressed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the ctrl-alt-del.target is masked and not active with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl status ctrl-alt-del.target{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}ctrl-alt-del.target{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Loaded: masked (/dev/null; bad){{{{newlineHERE}}}}Active: inactive (dead){{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the ctrl-alt-del.target is not masked, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the ctrl-alt-del.target is active, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the system to disable the Ctrl-Alt-Delete sequence for the command line with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl mask ctrl-alt-del.target

descs.check: Verify the operating system defines default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the value of the "UMASK" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" file with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If the value of the "UMASK" parameter is set to "000" in "/etc/login.defs" file, the Severity is raised to a CAT I.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i umask /etc/login.defs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UMASK 077{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value for the "UMASK" parameter is not "077", or the "UMASK" parameter is missing or is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add or edit the line for the "UMASK" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" file to "077":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UMASK 077

descs.check: Verify the version of the operating system is vendor supported.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the version of the operating system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cat /etc/redhat-release{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.4 (Maipo){{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current End of Life for RHEL 7.1 is 31 March 2017.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current End of Life for RHEL 7.2 is 30 November 2017.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current End of Life for RHEL 7.3 is 30 November 2018.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current End of Life for RHEL 7.4 is 31 August 2019.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current End of Life for RHEL 7.5 is 30 April 2020.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current End of Life for RHEL 7.6 is 31 October 2020.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Current End of Life for RHEL 7.7 is 30 August 2021.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the release is not supported by the vendor, this is a finding.

Verify the operating system security patches and updates are installed and up to date. Updates are required to be applied with a frequency determined by the site or Program Management Office (PMO). {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Obtain the list of available package security updates from Red Hat. The URL for updates is https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/. It is important to note that updates provided by Red Hat may not be present on the system if the underlying packages are not installed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the available package security updates have been installed on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum history list | more{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Loaded plugins: langpacks, product-id, subscription-manager{{{{newlineHERE}}}}ID | Command line | Date and time | Action(s) | Altered{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-------------------------------------------------------------------------------{{{{newlineHERE}}}} 70 | install aide | 2016-05-05 10:58 | Install | 1 {{{{newlineHERE}}}} 69 | update -y | 2016-05-04 14:34 | Update | 18 EE{{{{newlineHERE}}}} 68 | install vlc | 2016-04-21 17:12 | Install | 21 {{{{newlineHERE}}}} 67 | update -y | 2016-04-21 17:04 | Update | 7 EE{{{{newlineHERE}}}} 66 | update -y | 2016-04-15 16:47 | E, I, U | 84 EE{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If package updates have not been performed on the system within the timeframe that the site/program documentation requires, this is a finding. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Typical update frequency may be overridden by Information Assurance Vulnerability Alert (IAVA) notifications from CYBERCOM.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the operating system is in non-compliance with the Information Assurance Vulnerability Management (IAVM) process, this is a finding.

Verify all accounts on the system are assigned to an active system, application, or user account.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Obtain the list of authorized system accounts from the Information System Security Officer (ISSO).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the system accounts on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# more /etc/passwd{{{{newlineHERE}}}}root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash{{{{newlineHERE}}}}bin:x:1:1:bin:/bin:/sbin/nologin{{{{newlineHERE}}}}daemon:x:2:2:daemon:/sbin:/sbin/nologin{{{{newlineHERE}}}}sync:x:5:0:sync:/sbin:/bin/sync{{{{newlineHERE}}}}shutdown:x:6:0:shutdown:/sbin:/sbin/shutdown{{{{newlineHERE}}}}halt:x:7:0:halt:/sbin:/sbin/halt{{{{newlineHERE}}}}games:x:12:100:games:/usr/games:/sbin/nologin{{{{newlineHERE}}}}gopher:x:13:30:gopher:/var/gopher:/sbin/nologin{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Accounts such as "games" and "gopher" are not authorized accounts as they do not support authorized system functions. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the accounts on the system do not match the provided documentation, or accounts that do not support an authorized system function are present, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the system so all accounts on the system are assigned to an active system, application, or user account. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Remove accounts that do not support approved system activities or that allow for a normal user to perform administrative-level actions. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Document all authorized accounts on the system.

descs.check: Verify all GIDs referenced in the "/etc/passwd" file are defined in the "/etc/group" file.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that all referenced GIDs exist with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# pwck -r{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If GIDs referenced in "/etc/passwd" file are returned as not defined in "/etc/group" file, this is a finding.

Check the system for duplicate UID "0" assignments with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# awk -F: '$3 == 0 {print $1}' /etc/passwd{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any accounts other than root have a UID of "0", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the UID of any account on the system, other than root, that has a UID of "0". {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the account is associated with system commands or applications, the UID should be changed to one greater than "0" but less than "1000". Otherwise, assign a UID of greater than "1000" that has not already been assigned.

descs.check: Verify all files and directories on the system have a valid owner.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the owner of all files and directories with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The value after -fstype must be replaced with the filesystem type. XFS is used as an example.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -fstype xfs -nouser{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any files on the system do not have an assigned owner, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Either remove all files and directories from the system that do not have a valid user, or assign a valid user to all unowned files and directories on the system with the "chown" command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chown <user> <file>

descs.check: Verify all files and directories on the system have a valid group.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the owner of all files and directories with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The value after -fstype must be replaced with the filesystem type. XFS is used as an example.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -fstype xfs -nogroup{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any files on the system do not have an assigned group, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Either remove all files and directories from the system that do not have a valid group, or assign a valid group to all files and directories on the system with the "chgrp" command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chgrp <group> <file>

descs.check: Verify local interactive users on the system have a home directory assigned.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for missing local interactive user home directories with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# pwck -r{{{{newlineHERE}}}}user 'lp': directory '/var/spool/lpd' does not exist{{{{newlineHERE}}}}user 'news': directory '/var/spool/news' does not exist{{{{newlineHERE}}}}user 'uucp': directory '/var/spool/uucp' does not exist{{{{newlineHERE}}}}user 'smithj': directory '/home/smithj' does not exist{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Ask the System Administrator (SA) if any users found without home directories are local interactive users. If the SA is unable to provide a response, check for users with a User Identifier (UID) of 1000 or greater with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cut -d: -f 1,3 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any interactive users do not have a home directory assigned, this is a finding.

Verify all local interactive users on the system are assigned a home directory upon creation.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if the system is configured to create home directories for local interactive users with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i create_home /etc/login.defs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}CREATE_HOME yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value for "CREATE_HOME" parameter is not set to "yes", the line is missing, or the line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to assign home directories to all new local interactive users by setting the "CREATE_HOME" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" to "yes" as follows.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}CREATE_HOME yes

descs.check: Verify the assigned home directory of all local interactive users on the system exists.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the home directory assignment for all local interactive non-privileged users on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cut -d: -f 1,3,6 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{3}"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}smithj:1001:/home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged UID. Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files containing system logon information.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that all referenced home directories exist with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# pwck -r{{{{newlineHERE}}}}user 'smithj': directory '/home/smithj' does not exist{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any home directories referenced in "/etc/passwd" are returned as not defined, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Create home directories to all local interactive users that currently do not have a home directory assigned. Use the following commands to create the user home directory assigned in "/etc/ passwd":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj", a UID of "smithj", and a Group Identifier (GID) of "users" assigned in "/etc/passwd".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# mkdir /home/smithj {{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chown smithj /home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chgrp users /home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chmod 0750 /home/smithj

descs.check: Verify the assigned home directory of all local interactive users has a mode of "0750" or less permissive.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged User Identifier (UID). Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files containing system logon information.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -ld $(egrep ':[0-9]{4}' /etc/passwd | cut -d: -f6){{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-x--- 1 smithj users 18 Mar 5 17:06 /home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If home directories referenced in "/etc/passwd" do not have a mode of "0750" or less permissive, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the mode of interactive user's home directories to "0750". To change the mode of a local interactive user's home directory, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user "smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chmod 0750 /home/smithj

descs.check: Verify the assigned home directory of all local interactive users on the system exists.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the home directory assignment for all local interactive users on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -ld $(egrep ':[0-9]{4}' /etc/passwd | cut -d: -f6){{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-x--- 1 smithj users 18 Mar 5 17:06 /home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any home directories referenced in "/etc/passwd" are not owned by the interactive user, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the owner of a local interactive user's home directories to that owner. To change the owner of a local interactive user's home directory, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chown smithj /home/smithj

descs.check: Verify the assigned home directory of all local interactive users is group-owned by that user's primary GID.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the home directory assignment for all local interactive users on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -ld $(egrep ':[0-9]{4}' /etc/passwd | cut -d: -f6){{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-x--- 1 smithj users 18 Mar 5 17:06 /home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the user's primary group with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep users /etc/group{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}users:x:250:smithj,jonesj,jacksons{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the user home directory referenced in "/etc/passwd" is not group-owned by that user's primary GID, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the group owner of a local interactive user's home directory to the group found in "/etc/passwd". To change the group owner of a local interactive user's home directory, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user "smithj", who has a home directory of "/home/smithj", and has a primary group of users.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chgrp users /home/smithj

descs.check: Verify all files and directories in a local interactive user's home directory are owned by the user.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the owner of all files and directories in a local interactive user's home directory with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user "smithj", who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -lLR /home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 18 Mar 5 17:06 file1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 193 Mar 5 17:06 file2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 231 Mar 5 17:06 file3{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any files are found with an owner different than the home directory user, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the owner of a local interactive user's files and directories to that owner. To change the owner of a local interactive user's files and directories, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chown smithj /home/smithj/<file or directory>

descs.check: Verify all files and directories in a local interactive user home directory are group-owned by a group the user is a member of.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the group owner of all files and directories in a local interactive user's home directory with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user "smithj", who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -lLR /<home directory>/<users home directory>/{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 18 Mar 5 17:06 file1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 193 Mar 5 17:06 file2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 smithj sa 231 Mar 5 17:06 file3{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any files are found with an owner different than the group home directory user, check to see if the user is a member of that group with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep smithj /etc/group{{{{newlineHERE}}}}sa:x:100:juan,shelley,bob,smithj {{{{newlineHERE}}}}smithj:x:521:smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the user is not a member of a group that group owns file(s) in a local interactive user's home directory, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the group of a local interactive user's files and directories to a group that the interactive user is a member of. To change the group owner of a local interactive user's files and directories, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj" and is a member of the users group.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chgrp users /home/smithj/<file>

descs.check: Verify all files and directories contained in a local interactive user home directory, excluding local initialization files, have a mode of "0750".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the mode of all non-initialization files in a local interactive user home directory with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Files that begin with a "." are excluded from this requirement.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user "smithj", who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -lLR /home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-x--- 1 smithj smithj 18 Mar 5 17:06 file1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr----- 1 smithj smithj 193 Mar 5 17:06 file2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r-x--- 1 smithj smithj 231 Mar 5 17:06 file3{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any files are found with a mode more permissive than "0750", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the mode on files and directories in the local interactive user home directory with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj" and is a member of the users group.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chmod 0750 /home/smithj/<file>

descs.check: Verify the local initialization files of all local interactive users are owned by that user.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the smithj user, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cut -d: -f 1,3,6 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{3}"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}smithj:1000:/home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged User Identifier (UID). Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files containing system logon information.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the owner of all local interactive user's initialization files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /home/smithj/.[^.]* | more{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 896 Mar 10 2011 .profile{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 497 Jan 6 2007 .login{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 886 Jan 6 2007 .something{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If all local interactive user's initialization files are not owned by that user or root, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the owner of the local initialization files for interactive users to either the directory owner or root with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the smithj user, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chown smithj /home/smithj/.[^.]*

descs.check: Verify the local initialization files of all local interactive users are group-owned by that user's primary Group Identifier (GID).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the smithj user, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj" and a primary group of "users".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cut -d: -f 1,4,6 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{3}"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}smithj:1000:/home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep 1000 /etc/group{{{{newlineHERE}}}}users:x:1000:smithj,jonesj,jacksons {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged User Identifier (UID). Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files containing system logon information.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the group owner of all local interactive user's initialization files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /home/smithj/.[^.]* | more{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 896 Mar 10 2011 .profile{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 497 Jan 6 2007 .login{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 886 Jan 6 2007 .something{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If all local interactive user's initialization files are not group-owned by that user's primary GID, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the group owner of a local interactive user's files to the group found in "/etc/passwd" for the user. To change the group owner of a local interactive user's home directory, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj", and has a primary group of users.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chgrp users /home/smithj/.[^.]*

descs.check: Verify that all local initialization files have a mode of "0740" or less permissive.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the mode on all local initialization files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the "smithj" user, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /home/smithj/.[^.]* | more{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr----- 1 smithj users 896 Mar 10 2011 .profile{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr----- 1 smithj users 497 Jan 6 2007 .login{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rwxr----- 1 smithj users 886 Jan 6 2007 .something{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any local initialization files have a mode more permissive than "0740", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the mode of the local initialization files to "0740" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the "smithj" user, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chmod 0740 /home/smithj/.[^.]*

descs.check: Verify that all local interactive user initialization files' executable search path statements do not contain statements that will reference a working directory other than the users' home directory.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the executable search path statement for all local interactive user initialization files in the users' home directory with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for the smithj user, which has a home directory of "/home/smithj".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i path /home/smithj/.*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/home/smithj/.bash_profile:PATH=$PATH:$HOME/.local/bin:$HOME/bin{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/home/smithj/.bash_profile:export PATH{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any local interactive user initialization files have executable search path statements that include directories outside of their home directory, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Edit the local interactive user initialization files to change any PATH variable statements that reference directories other than their home directory. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a local interactive user requires path variables to reference a directory owned by the application, it must be documented with the ISSO.

descs.check: Verify that local initialization files do not execute world-writable programs.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the system for world-writable files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -xdev -perm -002 -type f -exec ls -ld {} \; | more{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}For all files listed, check for their presence in the local initialization files with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example will be for a system that is configured to create users' home directories in the "/home" directory.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep <file> /home/*/.*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any local initialization files are found to reference world-writable files, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the mode on files being executed by the local initialization files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chmod 0755 <file>

descs.check: Verify that all system device files are correctly labeled to prevent unauthorized modification.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}List all device files on the system that are incorrectly labeled with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: Device files are normally found under "/dev", but applications may place device files in other directories and may necessitate a search of the entire system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#find /dev -context *:device_t:* \( -type c -o -type b \) -printf "%p %Z "{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#find /dev -context *:unlabeled_t:* \( -type c -o -type b \) -printf "%p %Z "{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: There are device files, such as "/dev/vmci", that are used when the operating system is a host virtual machine. They will not be owned by a user on the system and require the "device_t" label to operate. These device files are not a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is output from either of these commands, other than already noted, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Run the following command to determine which package owns the device file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rpm -qf <filename>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The package can be reinstalled from a yum repository using the command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sudo yum reinstall <packagename>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Alternatively, the package can be reinstalled from trusted media using the command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sudo rpm -Uvh <packagename>

descs.check: Verify file systems that contain user home directories are mounted with the "nosuid" option.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Find the file system(s) that contain the user home directories with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If a separate file system has not been created for the user home directories (user home directories are mounted under "/"), this is not a finding as the "nosuid" option cannot be used on the "/" system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cut -d: -f 1,3,6 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{3}"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}smithj:1001:/home/smithj{{{{newlineHERE}}}}thomasr:1002:/home/thomasr{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the file systems that are mounted at boot time with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# more /etc/fstab{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UUID=a411dc99-f2a1-4c87-9e05-184977be8539 /home ext4 rw,relatime,discard,data=ordered,nosuid 0 2{{{{newlineHERE}}}} {{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a file system found in "/etc/fstab" refers to the user home directory file system and it does not have the "nosuid" option set, this is a finding.

Verify file systems that are used for removable media are mounted with the "nosuid" option.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the file systems that are mounted at boot time with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# more /etc/fstab{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UUID=2bc871e4-e2a3-4f29-9ece-3be60c835222 /mnt/usbflash vfat noauto,owner,ro,nosuid 0 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a file system found in "/etc/fstab" refers to removable media and it does not have the "nosuid" option set, this is a finding.

Verify file systems that are being NFS imported are configured with the "nosuid" option.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Find the file system(s) that contain the directories being exported with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# more /etc/fstab | grep nfs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UUID=e06097bb-cfcd-437b-9e4d-a691f5662a7d /store nfs rw,nosuid 0 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a file system found in "/etc/fstab" refers to NFS and it does not have the "nosuid" option set, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the NFS is mounted with the "nosuid" option:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# mount | grep nfs | grep nosuid{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If no results are returned, this is a finding.

V-72047.desc: If a world-writable directory has the sticky bit set and is not group-owned by a privileged Group Identifier (GID), unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.

descs.check: Verify all world-writable directories are group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the system for world-writable directories with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The value after -fstype must be replaced with the filesystem type. XFS is used as an example.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -xdev -perm -002 -type d -fstype xfs -exec ls -lLd {} \;{{{{newlineHERE}}}}drwxrwxrwt 2 root root 40 Aug 26 13:07 /dev/mqueue{{{{newlineHERE}}}}drwxrwxrwt 2 root root 220 Aug 26 13:23 /dev/shm{{{{newlineHERE}}}}drwxrwxrwt 14 root root 4096 Aug 26 13:29 /tmp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any world-writable directories are not owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group associated with the directory, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Change the group of the world-writable directories to root with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chgrp root <directory>

descs.check: Verify that the default umask for all local interactive users is "077".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Identify the locations of all local interactive user home directories by looking at the "/etc/passwd" file.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check all local interactive user initialization files for interactive users with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example is for a system that is configured to create users home directories in the "/home" directory.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i umask /home/*/.*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any local interactive user initialization files are found to have a umask statement that has a value less restrictive than "077", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Remove the umask statement from all local interactive user's initialization files. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the account is for an application, the requirement for a umask less restrictive than "077" can be documented with the Information System Security Officer, but the user agreement for access to the account must specify that the local interactive user must log on to their account first and then switch the user to the application account with the correct option to gain the account's environment variables.
