descs.check: Verify that "rsyslog" is configured to log cron events.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the configuration of "/etc/rsyslog.conf" or "/etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf" files for the cron facility with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If another logging package is used, substitute the utility configuration file for "/etc/rsyslog.conf" or "/etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf" files.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep cron /etc/rsyslog.conf /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}cron.* /var/log/cron.log{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the command does not return a response, check for cron logging all facilities by inspecting the "/etc/rsyslog.conf" or "/etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf" files.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Look for the following entry:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}*.* /var/log/messages{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "rsyslog" is not logging messages for the cron facility or all facilities, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure "rsyslog" to log all cron messages by adding or updating the following line to "/etc/rsyslog.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/rsyslog.d/ directory:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}cron.* /var/log/cron.log

descs.check: Verify that the "cron.allow" file is owned by root.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the owner of the "cron.allow" file with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/cron.allow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw------- 1 root root 6 Mar 5 2011 /etc/cron.allow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "cron.allow" file exists and has an owner other than root, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the owner on the "/etc/cron.allow" file to root with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chown root /etc/cron.allow

descs.check: Verify that the "cron.allow" file is group-owned by root.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the group owner of the "cron.allow" file with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/cron.allow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw------- 1 root root 6 Mar 5 2011 /etc/cron.allow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "cron.allow" file exists and has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the group owner on the "/etc/cron.allow" file to root with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chgrp root /etc/cron.allow

descs.check: Verify that kernel core dumps are disabled unless needed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the status of the "kdump" service with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl status kdump.service{{{{newlineHERE}}}}kdump.service - Crash recovery kernel arming{{{{newlineHERE}}}} Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/kdump.service; enabled){{{{newlineHERE}}}} Active: active (exited) since Wed 2015-08-26 13:08:09 EDT; 43min ago{{{{newlineHERE}}}} Main PID: 1130 (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS){{{{newlineHERE}}}}kernel arming.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "kdump" service is active, ask the System Administrator if the use of the service is required and documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the service is active and is not documented, this is a finding.
descs.fix: If kernel core dumps are not required, disable the "kdump" service with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl disable kdump.service{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If kernel core dumps are required, document the need with the ISSO.

descs.check: Verify that a separate file system/partition has been created for non-privileged local interactive user home directories.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users (those with a UID greater than 1000) on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#cut -d: -f 1,3,6,7 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{3}" | tr ":" "\t"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}adamsj /home/adamsj /bin/bash{{{{newlineHERE}}}}jacksonm /home/jacksonm /bin/bash{{{{newlineHERE}}}}smithj /home/smithj /bin/bash{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The output of the command will give the directory/partition that contains the home directories for the non-privileged users on the system (in this example, /home) and users' shell. All accounts with a valid shell (such as /bin/bash) are considered interactive users.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that a file system/partition has been created for the non-privileged interactive users with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The partition of /home is used in the example.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep /home /etc/fstab{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UUID=333ada18 /home ext4 noatime,nobarrier,nodev 1 2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a separate entry for the file system/partition that contains the non-privileged interactive users' home directories does not exist, this is a finding.

Verify that a separate file system/partition has been created for "/var".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that a file system/partition has been created for "/var" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep /var /etc/fstab{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UUID=c274f65f /var ext4 noatime,nobarrier 1 2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a separate entry for "/var" is not in use, this is a finding.

Determine if the operating system is configured to have the "/var/log/audit" path is on a separate file system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep /var/log/audit /etc/fstab{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If no result is returned, or the operating system is not configured to have "/var/log/audit" on a separate file system, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify that "/var/log/audit" is mounted on a separate file system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# mount | grep "/var/log/audit"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If no result is returned, or "/var/log/audit" is not on a separate file system, this is a finding.

Verify that a separate file system/partition has been created for "/tmp".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that a file system/partition has been created for "/tmp" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl is-enabled tmp.mount{{{{newlineHERE}}}}enabled{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "tmp.mount" service is not enabled, check to see if "/tmp" is defined in the fstab with a device and mount point:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i /tmp /etc/fstab{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UUID=a411dc99-f2a1-4c87-9e05-184977be8539 /tmp ext4 rw,relatime,discard,data=ordered,nosuid,noexec, 0 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "tmp.mount" service is not enabled and the "/tmp" directory is not defined in the fstab with a device and mount point, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Start the "tmp.mount" service with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl enable tmp.mount{{{{newlineHERE}}}} {{{{newlineHERE}}}}OR{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Edit the "/etc/fstab" file and ensure the "/tmp" directory is defined in the fstab with a device and mount point.

V-72067.desc: Use of weak or untested encryption algorithms undermines the purposes of using encryption to protect data. The operating system must implement cryptographic modules adhering to the higher standards approved by the federal government since this provides assurance they have been tested and validated.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system implements DoD-approved encryption to protect the confidentiality of remote access sessions.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if the "dracut-fips" package is installed with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed dracut-fips{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}dracut-fips-033-360.el7_2.x86_64.rpm{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a "dracut-fips" package is installed, check to see if the kernel command line is configured to use FIPS mode with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: GRUB 2 reads its configuration from the "/boot/grub2/grub.cfg" file on traditional BIOS-based machines and from the "/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg" file on UEFI machines.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep fips /boot/grub2/grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/vmlinuz-3.8.0-0.40.el7.x86_64 root=/dev/mapper/rhel-root ro rd.md=0 rd.dm=0 rd.lvm.lv=rhel/swap crashkernel=auto rd.luks=0 vconsole.keymap=us rd.lvm.lv=rhel/root rhgb fips=1 quiet{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the kernel command line is configured to use FIPS mode, check to see if the system is in FIPS mode with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cat /proc/sys/crypto/fips_enabled {{{{newlineHERE}}}}1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a "dracut-fips" package is not installed, the kernel command line does not have a fips entry, or the system has a value of "0" for "fips_enabled" in "/proc/sys/crypto", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to implement DoD-approved encryption by installing the dracut-fips package.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To enable strict FIPS compliance, the fips=1 kernel option needs to be added to the kernel command line during system installation so key generation is done with FIPS-approved algorithms and continuous monitoring tests in place.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Configure the operating system to implement DoD-approved encryption by following the steps below: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The fips=1 kernel option needs to be added to the kernel command line during system installation so that key generation is done with FIPS-approved algorithms and continuous monitoring tests in place. Users should also ensure that the system has plenty of entropy during the installation process by moving the mouse around, or if no mouse is available, ensuring that many keystrokes are typed. The recommended amount of keystrokes is 256 and more. Less than 256 keystrokes may generate a non-unique key.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Install the dracut-fips package with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum install dracut-fips{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Recreate the "initramfs" file with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: This command will overwrite the existing "initramfs" file.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# dracut -f{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Modify the kernel command line of the current kernel in the "grub.cfg" file by adding the following option to the GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX key in the "/etc/default/grub" file and then rebuild the "grub.cfg" file:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}fips=1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Changes to "/etc/default/grub" require rebuilding the "grub.cfg" file as follows:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}On BIOS-based machines, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}On UEFI-based machines, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If /boot or /boot/efi reside on separate partitions, the kernel parameter boot=<partition of /boot or /boot/efi> must be added to the kernel command line. You can identify a partition by running the df /boot or df /boot/efi command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# df /boot{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Filesystem 1K-blocks Used Available Use% Mounted on{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/dev/sda1 495844 53780 416464 12% /boot{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To ensure the "boot=" configuration option will work even if device naming changes occur between boots, identify the universally unique identifier (UUID) of the partition with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# blkid /dev/sda1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/dev/sda1: UUID="05c000f1-a213-759e-c7a2-f11b7424c797" TYPE="ext4"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}For the example above, append the following string to the kernel command line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}boot=UUID=05c000f1-a213-759e-c7a2-f11b7424c797{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Reboot the system for the changes to take effect.

descs.check: Verify the file integrity tool is configured to verify ACLs.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment (AIDE) is installed on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is not installed, ask the System Administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no application installed to perform file integrity checks, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: AIDE is highly configurable at install time. These commands assume the "aide.conf" file is under the "/etc" directory. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name aide.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the "aide.conf" file to determine if the "acl" rule has been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}An example rule that includes the "acl" rule is below:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}All= p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin {{{{newlineHERE}}}}/sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "acl" rule is not being used on all uncommented selection lines in the "/etc/aide.conf" file, or ACLs are not being checked by another file integrity tool, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the file integrity tool to check file and directory ACLs. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is installed, ensure the "acl" rule is present on all uncommented file and directory selection lists.

descs.check: Verify the file integrity tool is configured to verify extended attributes.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment (AIDE) is installed on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is not installed, ask the System Administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no application installed to perform file integrity checks, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: AIDE is highly configurable at install time. These commands assume the "aide.conf" file is under the "/etc" directory.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name aide.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the "aide.conf" file to determine if the "xattrs" rule has been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}An example rule that includes the "xattrs" rule follows:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}All= p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin {{{{newlineHERE}}}}/sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "xattrs" rule is not being used on all uncommented selection lines in the "/etc/aide.conf" file, or extended attributes are not being checked by another file integrity tool, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the file integrity tool to check file and directory extended attributes. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is installed, ensure the "xattrs" rule is present on all uncommented file and directory selection lists.

descs.check: Verify the file integrity tool is configured to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents and directories.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If RHEL-07-021350 is a finding, this is automatically a finding too as the system cannot implement FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic algorithms and hashes.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment (AIDE) is installed on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed aide{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is not installed, ask the System Administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no application installed to perform file integrity checks, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: AIDE is highly configurable at install time. These commands assume the "aide.conf" file is under the "/etc" directory. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name aide.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the "aide.conf" file to determine if the "sha512" rule has been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}An example rule that includes the "sha512" rule follows:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}All=p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin {{{{newlineHERE}}}}/sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "sha512" rule is not being used on all uncommented selection lines in the "/etc/aide.conf" file, or another file integrity tool is not using FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents and directories, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the file integrity tool to use FIPS 140-2 cryptographic hashes for validating file and directory contents. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If AIDE is installed, ensure the "sha512" rule is present on all uncommented file and directory selection lists.

descs.check: Verify the system is not configured to use a boot loader on removable media.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: GRUB 2 reads its configuration from the "/boot/grub2/grub.cfg" file on traditional BIOS-based machines and from the "/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg" file on UEFI machines.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the existence of alternate boot loader configuration files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/boot/grub2/grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a "grub.cfg" is found in any subdirectories other than "/boot/grub2" and "/boot/efi/EFI/redhat", ask the System Administrator if there is documentation signed by the ISSO to approve the use of removable media as a boot loader. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the grub configuration file has the set root command in each menu entry with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -c menuentry /boot/grub2/grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep 'set root' /boot/grub2/grub.cfg{{{{newlineHERE}}}}set root=(hd0,1){{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the system is using an alternate boot loader on removable media, and documentation does not exist approving the alternate configuration, this is a finding.

V-72077.desc: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Examples of non-essential capabilities include, but are not limited to, games, software packages, tools, and demonstration software not related to requirements or providing a wide array of functionality not required for every mission, but which cannot be disabled.

descs.check: Verify the operating system is configured to disable non-essential capabilities. The most secure way of ensuring a non-essential capability is disabled is to not have the capability installed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The telnet service provides an unencrypted remote access service that does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a privileged user were to log on using this service, the privileged user password could be compromised. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if the telnet-server package is installed with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed telnet-server{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the telnet-server package is installed, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to disable non-essential capabilities by removing the telnet-server package from the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum remove telnet-server

V-72079.desc: Without establishing what type of events occurred, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events leading up to an outage or attack.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Audit record content that may be necessary to satisfy this requirement includes, for example, time stamps, source and destination addresses, user/process identifiers, event descriptions, success/fail indications, filenames involved, and access control or flow control rules invoked.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Associating event types with detected events in the operating system audit logs provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured operating system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system produces audit records containing information to establish when (date and time) the events occurred.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if auditing is active by issuing the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl is-active auditd.service{{{{newlineHERE}}}}active{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "auditd" status is not active, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to produce audit records containing information to establish when (date and time) the events occurred.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Enable the auditd service with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl start auditd.service

V-72081.desc: It is critical for the appropriate personnel to be aware if a system is at risk of failing to process audit logs as required. Without this notification, the security personnel may be unaware of an impending failure of the audit capability, and system operation may be adversely affected.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Audit processing failures include software/hardware errors, failures in the audit capturing mechanisms, and audit storage capacity being reached or exceeded.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement applies to each audit data storage repository (i.e., distinct information system component where audit records are stored), the centralized audit storage capacity of organizations (i.e., all audit data storage repositories combined), or both.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Confirm the audit configuration regarding how auditing processing failures are handled.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see what level "auditctl" is set to with following command: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# auditctl -s | grep -i "fail"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}failure 2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If the value of "failure" is set to "2", the system is configured to panic (shut down) in the event of an auditing failure. If the value of "failure" is set to "1", the system is configured to only send information to the kernel log regarding the failure.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "failure" setting is set to any value other than "1" or "2", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "failure" setting is not set, this should be upgraded to a CAT I finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "failure" setting is set to "1" but the availability concern is not documented or there is no monitoring of the kernel log, this should be downgraded to a CAT III finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to shut down in the event of an audit processing failure.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add or correct the option to shut down the operating system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# auditctl -f 2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-f 2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If availability has been determined to be more important, and this decision is documented with the ISSO, configure the operating system to notify system administration staff and ISSO staff in the event of an audit processing failure with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# auditctl -f 1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-f 1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Kernel log monitoring must also be configured to properly alert designated staff.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.

V-72083.desc: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system off-loads audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To determine the remote server that the records are being sent to, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i remote_server /etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}remote_server = 10.0.21.1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a remote server is not configured, or the line is commented out, ask the System Administrator to indicate how the audit logs are off-loaded to a different system or media. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no evidence that the audit logs are being off-loaded to another system or media, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to off-load audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the remote server option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" with the IP address of the log aggregation server.

V-72085.desc: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system encrypts audit records off-loaded onto a different system or media from the system being audited.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To determine if the transfer is encrypted, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i enable_krb5 /etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}enable_krb5 = yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value of the "enable_krb5" option is not set to "yes" or the line is commented out, ask the System Administrator to indicate how the audit logs are off-loaded to a different system or media. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no evidence that the transfer of the audit logs being off-loaded to another system or media is encrypted, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to encrypt the transfer of off-loaded audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Uncomment the "enable_krb5" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it with the following line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}enable_krb5 = yes

descs.check: Verify the action the operating system takes if the disk the audit records are written to becomes full.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To determine the action that takes place if the disk is full on the remote server, use the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i disk_full_action /etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}disk_full_action = single{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value of the "disk_full_action" option is not "syslog", "single", or "halt", or the line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the action the operating system takes if the disk the audit records are written to becomes full.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Uncomment or edit the "disk_full_action" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it to "syslog", "single", or "halt", such as the following line:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}disk_full_action = single

descs.check: Verify the operating system initiates an action to notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are being written to with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -iw log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}log_file = /var/log/audit/audit.log{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the example being "/var/log/audit/"):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# df -h /var/log/audit/{{{{newlineHERE}}}}0.9G /var/log/audit{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the audit records are not being written to a partition specifically created for audit records (in this example "/var/log/audit" is a separate partition), determine the amount of space other files in the partition are currently occupying with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# du -sh <partition>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}1.8G /var{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Determine what the threshold is for the system to take action when 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -iw space_left /etc/audit/auditd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}space_left = 225 {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value of the "space_left" keyword is not set to 25 percent of the total partition size, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to initiate an action to notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are being written to: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -iw log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Determine the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the example being "/var/log/audit/"):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# df -h /var/log/audit/{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the value of the "space_left" keyword in "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" to 25 percent of the partition size.

descs.check: Verify the operating system immediately notifies the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) via email when the allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check what action the operating system takes when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i space_left_action /etc/audit/auditd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}space_left_action = email{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value of the "space_left_action" keyword is not set to "email", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to immediately notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Uncomment or edit the "space_left_action" keyword in "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" and set it to "email". {{{{newlineHERE}}}} {{{{newlineHERE}}}}space_left_action = email

descs.check: Verify the operating system immediately notifies the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) via email when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check what account the operating system emails when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i action_mail_acct /etc/audit/auditd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}action_mail_acct = root{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value of the "action_mail_acct" keyword is not set to "root" and other accounts for security personnel, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to immediately notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Uncomment or edit the "action_mail_acct" keyword in "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" and set it to root and any other accounts associated with security personnel. {{{{newlineHERE}}}} {{{{newlineHERE}}}}action_mail_acct = root

descs.check: Verify the operating system audits the execution of privileged functions using the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -iw execve /etc/audit/audit.rules{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S execve -C uid!=euid -F euid=0 -k setuid{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S execve -C uid!=euid -F euid=0 -k setuid{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S execve -C gid!=egid -F egid=0 -k setgid{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S execve -C gid!=egid -F egid=0 -k setgid{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If both the "b32" and "b64" audit rules for "SUID" files are not defined, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If both the "b32" and "b64" audit rules for "SGID" files are not defined, this is a finding.

descs.check: Verify "rsyslog" is configured to send all messages to a log aggregation server.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the configuration of "rsyslog" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If another logging package is used, substitute the utility configuration file for "/etc/rsyslog.conf".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep @ /etc/rsyslog.conf /etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}*.* @@logagg.site.mil{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there are no lines in the "/etc/rsyslog.conf" or "/etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf" files that contain the "@" or "@@" symbol(s), and the lines with the correct symbol(s) to send output to another system do not cover all "rsyslog" output, ask the System Administrator to indicate how the audit logs are off-loaded to a different system or media. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the lines are commented out or there is no evidence that the audit logs are being sent to another system, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Modify the "/etc/rsyslog.conf" or an "/etc/rsyslog.d/*.conf" file to contain a configuration line to send all "rsyslog" output to a log aggregation system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}*.* @@<log aggregation system name>

V-72211.desc: Unintentionally running a rsyslog server accepting remote messages puts the system at increased risk. Malicious rsyslog messages sent to the server could exploit vulnerabilities in the server software itself, could introduce misleading information in to the system's logs, or could fill the system's storage leading to a Denial of Service.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the system is intended to be a log aggregation server its use must be documented with the ISSO.

descs.check: Verify that the system is not accepting "rsyslog" messages from other systems unless it is documented as a log aggregation server.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the configuration of "rsyslog" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep imtcp /etc/rsyslog.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}$ModLoad imtcp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep imudp /etc/rsyslog.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}$ModLoad imudp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep imrelp /etc/rsyslog.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}$ModLoad imrelp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any of the above modules are being loaded in the "/etc/rsyslog.conf" file, ask to see the documentation for the system being used for log aggregation.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the documentation does not exist, or does not specify the server as a log aggregation system, this is a finding.

V-72213.desc: Virus scanning software can be used to protect a system from penetration from computer viruses and to limit their spread through intermediate systems. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The virus scanning software should be configured to perform scans dynamically on accessed files. If this capability is not available, the system must be configured to scan, at a minimum, all altered files on the system on a daily basis.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the system processes inbound SMTP mail, the virus scanner must be configured to scan all received mail.

descs.check: Verify an anti-virus solution is installed on the system. The anti-virus solution may be bundled with an approved host-based security solution.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there is no anti-virus solution installed on the system, this is a finding.

V-72217.desc: Operating system management includes the ability to control the number of users and user sessions that utilize an operating system. Limiting the number of allowed users and sessions per user is helpful in reducing the risks related to DoS attacks.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for information system accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by single users via multiple system accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions should be defined based on mission needs and the operational environment for each system.

descs.check: Verify the operating system limits the number of concurrent sessions to "10" for all accounts and/or account types by issuing the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep "maxlogins" /etc/security/limits.conf /etc/security/limits.d/*.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}* hard maxlogins 10{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This can be set as a global domain (with the * wildcard) but may be set differently for multiple domains.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "maxlogins" item is missing, commented out, or the value is not set to "10" or less for all domains that have the "maxlogins" item assigned, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to limit the number of concurrent sessions to "10" for all accounts and/or account types.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line to the top of the /etc/security/limits.conf or in a ".conf" file defined in /etc/security/limits.d/ :{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}* hard maxlogins 10

V-72219.desc: In order to prevent unauthorized connection of devices, unauthorized transfer of information, or unauthorized tunneling (i.e., embedding of data types within data types), organizations must disable or restrict unused or unnecessary physical and logical ports/protocols on information systems.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services provided by default may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations. Additionally, it is sometimes convenient to provide multiple services from a single component (e.g., VPN and IPS); however, doing so increases risk over limiting the services provided by any one component.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To support the requirements and principles of least functionality, the operating system must support the organizational requirements, providing only essential capabilities and limiting the use of ports, protocols, and/or services to only those required, authorized, and approved to conduct official business or to address authorized quality of life issues.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Inspect the firewall configuration and running services to verify that it is configured to prohibit or restrict the use of functions, ports, protocols, and/or services that are unnecessary or prohibited.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check which services are currently active with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# firewall-cmd --list-all{{{{newlineHERE}}}}public (default, active){{{{newlineHERE}}}} interfaces: enp0s3{{{{newlineHERE}}}} sources: {{{{newlineHERE}}}} services: dhcpv6-client dns http https ldaps rpc-bind ssh{{{{newlineHERE}}}} ports: {{{{newlineHERE}}}} masquerade: no{{{{newlineHERE}}}} forward-ports: {{{{newlineHERE}}}} icmp-blocks: {{{{newlineHERE}}}} rich rules: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Ask the System Administrator for the site or program PPSM CLSA. Verify the services allowed by the firewall match the PPSM CLSA. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there are additional ports, protocols, or services that are not in the PPSM CLSA, or there are ports, protocols, or services that are prohibited by the PPSM Category Assurance List (CAL), this is a finding.

V-72221.desc: Unapproved mechanisms that are used for authentication to the cryptographic module are not verified and therefore cannot be relied upon to provide confidentiality or integrity, and DoD data may be compromised.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Operating systems utilizing encryption are required to use FIPS-compliant mechanisms for authenticating to cryptographic modules.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}FIPS 140-2 is the current standard for validating that mechanisms used to access cryptographic modules utilize authentication that meets DoD requirements. This allows for Security Levels 1, 2, 3, or 4 for use on a general purpose computing system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system uses mechanisms meeting the requirements of applicable federal laws, Executive orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance for authentication to a cryptographic module.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If RHEL-07-021350 is a finding, this is automatically a finding as the system cannot implement FIPS 140-2-approved cryptographic algorithms and hashes.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The location of the "sshd_config" file may vary if a different daemon is in use.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Inspect the "Ciphers" configuration with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i ciphers /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Ciphers aes128-ctr,aes192-ctr,aes256-ctr{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any ciphers other than "aes128-ctr", "aes192-ctr", or "aes256-ctr" are listed, the "Ciphers" keyword is missing, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure SSH to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic algorithms.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line (or modify the line to have the required value) to the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Ciphers aes128-ctr,aes192-ctr,aes256-ctr{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

V-72223.desc: Terminating an idle session within a short time period reduces the window of opportunity for unauthorized personnel to take control of a management session enabled on the console or console port that has been left unattended. In addition, quickly terminating an idle session will also free up resources committed by the managed network element. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Terminating network connections associated with communications sessions includes, for example, de-allocating associated TCP/IP address/port pairs at the operating system level and de-allocating networking assignments at the application level if multiple application sessions are using a single operating system-level network connection. This does not mean that the operating system terminates all sessions or network access; it only ends the inactive session and releases the resources associated with that session.

descs.check: Verify the operating system terminates all network connections associated with a communications session at the end of the session or based on inactivity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the value of the system inactivity timeout with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i tmout /etc/profile.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}etc/profile.d/tmout.sh:TMOUT=600{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/etc/profile.d/tmout.sh:readonly TMOUT{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/etc/profile.d/tmout.sh:export TMOUT{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "TMOUT" is not set to "600" or less in a script located in the /etc/profile.d/ directory to enforce session termination after inactivity, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to terminate all network connections associated with a communications session at the end of the session or after a period of inactivity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Create a script to enforce the inactivity timeout (for example /etc/profile.d/tmout.sh) such as:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#!/bin/bash{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}TMOUT=600{{{{newlineHERE}}}}readonly TMOUT{{{{newlineHERE}}}}export TMOUT

V-72227.desc: Without cryptographic integrity protections, information can be altered by unauthorized users without detection.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Cryptographic mechanisms used for protecting the integrity of information include, for example, signed hash functions using asymmetric cryptography enabling distribution of the public key to verify the hash information while maintaining the confidentiality of the key used to generate the hash.

V-72233.desc: Without protection of the transmitted information, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and either read or altered. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement applies to both internal and external networks and all types of information system components from which information can be transmitted (e.g., servers, mobile devices, notebook computers, printers, copiers, scanners, and facsimile machines). Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of organizational information can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical distribution systems) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

V-72237.desc: Terminating an idle SSH session within a short time period reduces the window of opportunity for unauthorized personnel to take control of a management session enabled on the console or console port that has been left unattended. In addition, quickly terminating an idle SSH session will also free up resources committed by the managed network element.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Terminating network connections associated with communications sessions includes, for example, de-allocating associated TCP/IP address/port pairs at the operating system level and de-allocating networking assignments at the application level if multiple application sessions are using a single operating system-level network connection. This does not mean that the operating system terminates all sessions or network access; it only ends the inactive session and releases the resources associated with that session.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system automatically terminates a user session after inactivity time-outs have expired.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the value of the "ClientAliveInterval" keyword with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -iw clientaliveinterval /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}ClientAliveInterval 600{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "ClientAliveInterval" is not configured, commented out, or has a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "ClientAliveInterval" has a value that is greater than "600" and is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO) as an operational requirement, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to automatically terminate a user session after inactivity time-outs have expired or at shutdown.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line (or modify the line to have the required value) to the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}ClientAliveInterval 600{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

descs.check: Check the version of the operating system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cat /etc/redhat-release{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the release is 7.4 or newer this requirement is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the SSH daemon does not allow authentication using RSA rhosts authentication.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To determine how the SSH daemon's "RhostsRSAAuthentication" option is set, run the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep RhostsRSAAuthentication /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}RhostsRSAAuthentication no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value is returned as "yes", the returned line is commented out, or no output is returned, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the SSH daemon to not allow authentication using RSA rhosts authentication.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config", or uncomment the line and set the value to "no":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}RhostsRSAAuthentication no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

descs.check: Verify the SSH daemon does not allow authentication using known hosts authentication.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To determine how the SSH daemon's "IgnoreRhosts" option is set, run the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i IgnoreRhosts /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}IgnoreRhosts yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the value is returned as "no", the returned line is commented out, or no output is returned, this is a finding.
