descs.fix: Remove all Protocol lines that reference version "1" in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor). The "Protocol" line must be as follows:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Protocol 2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

descs.check: Verify the SSH daemon is configured to only use MACs employing FIPS 140-2-approved ciphers.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If RHEL-07-021350 is a finding, this is automatically a finding as the system cannot implement FIPS 140-2-approved cryptographic algorithms and hashes.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the SSH daemon is configured to only use MACs employing FIPS 140-2-approved ciphers with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i macs /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}MACs hmac-sha2-256,hmac-sha2-512{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any ciphers other than "hmac-sha2-256" or "hmac-sha2-512" are listed or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "MACs" keyword and set its value to "hmac-sha2-256" and/or "hmac-sha2-512" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}MACs hmac-sha2-256,hmac-sha2-512{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

descs.check: Verify the SSH public host key files have mode "0644" or less permissive.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: SSH public key files may be found in other directories on the system depending on the installation.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The following command will find all SSH public key files on the system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find /etc/ssh -name '*.pub' -exec ls -lL {} \;{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 618 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_dsa_key.pub{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 347 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_key.pub{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 238 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_rsa_key.pub{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any file has a mode more permissive than "0644", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Note: SSH public key files may be found in other directories on the system depending on the installation. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Change the mode of public host key files under "/etc/ssh" to "0644" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chmod 0644 /etc/ssh/*.key.pub

descs.check: Verify the SSH private host key files have mode "0640" or less permissive.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The following command will find all SSH private key files on the system and list their modes:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name '*ssh_host*key' | xargs ls -lL{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r----- 1 root ssh_keys 668 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_dsa_key{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r----- 1 root ssh_keys 582 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_key{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r----- 1 root ssh_keys 887 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_rsa_key{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any file has a mode more permissive than "0640", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the mode of SSH private host key files under "/etc/ssh" to "0640" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chmod 0640 /path/to/file/ssh_host*key

descs.check: Verify the SSH daemon does not permit GSSAPI authentication unless approved.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the SSH daemon does not permit GSSAPI authentication with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i gssapiauth /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}GSSAPIAuthentication no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "GSSAPIAuthentication" keyword is missing, is set to "yes" and is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO), or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Uncomment the "GSSAPIAuthentication" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) and set the value to "no": {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}GSSAPIAuthentication no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If GSSAPI authentication is required, it must be documented, to include the location of the configuration file, with the ISSO.

descs.check: Verify the SSH daemon does not permit Kerberos to authenticate passwords unless approved.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the SSH daemon does not permit Kerberos to authenticate passwords with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i kerberosauth /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}KerberosAuthentication no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "KerberosAuthentication" keyword is missing, or is set to "yes" and is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO), or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Uncomment the "KerberosAuthentication" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) and set the value to "no":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}KerberosAuthentication no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If Kerberos authentication is required, it must be documented, to include the location of the configuration file, with the ISSO.

descs.check: Verify the SSH daemon performs strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The location of the "sshd_config" file may vary if a different daemon is in use.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Inspect the "sshd_config" file with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i strictmodes /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}StrictModes yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "StrictModes" is set to "no", is missing, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Uncomment the "StrictModes" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) and set the value to "yes":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}StrictModes yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

descs.check: Verify the SSH daemon performs privilege separation.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the SSH daemon performs privilege separation with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i usepriv /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UsePrivilegeSeparation sandbox{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "UsePrivilegeSeparation" keyword is set to "no", is missing, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Uncomment the "UsePrivilegeSeparation" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) and set the value to "sandbox" or "yes":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}UsePrivilegeSeparation sandbox{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

descs.check: Verify the SSH daemon performs compression after a user successfully authenticates.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the SSH daemon performs compression after a user successfully authenticates with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i compression /etc/ssh/sshd_config{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Compression delayed{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "Compression" keyword is set to "yes", is missing, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Uncomment the "Compression" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) on the system and set the value to "delayed" or "no":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Compression no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

V-72269.desc: Inaccurate time stamps make it more difficult to correlate events and can lead to an inaccurate analysis. Determining the correct time a particular event occurred on a system is critical when conducting forensic analysis and investigating system events. Sources outside the configured acceptable allowance (drift) may be inaccurate.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Synchronizing internal information system clocks provides uniformity of time stamps for information systems with multiple system clocks and systems connected over a network.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Organizations should consider endpoints that may not have regular access to the authoritative time server (e.g., mobile, teleworking, and tactical endpoints).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Check to see if NTP is running in continuous mode:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ps -ef | grep ntp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If NTP is not running, check to see if "chronyd" is running in continuous mode:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ps -ef | grep chronyd{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If NTP or "chronyd" is not running, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the NTP process is found, then check the "ntp.conf" file for the "maxpoll" option setting:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep maxpoll /etc/ntp.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}server 0.rhel.pool.ntp.org iburst maxpoll 10{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the option is set to "17" or is not set, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file does not exist, check the "/etc/cron.daily" subdirectory for a crontab file controlling the execution of the "ntpd -q" command.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i "ntpd -q" /etc/cron.daily/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/cron.* | grep ntp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}ntp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a crontab file does not exist in the "/etc/cron.daily" that executes the "ntpd -q" command, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "chronyd" process is found, then check the "chrony.conf" file for the "maxpoll" option setting:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep maxpoll /etc/chrony.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}server 0.rhel.pool.ntp.org iburst maxpoll 10{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the option is not set or the line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Edit the "/etc/ntp.conf" or "/etc/chrony.conf" file and add or update an entry to define "maxpoll" to "10" as follows:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}server 0.rhel.pool.ntp.org iburst maxpoll 10{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If NTP was running and "maxpoll" was updated, the NTP service must be restarted:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl restart ntpd{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If NTP was not running, it must be started:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl start ntpd {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "chronyd" was running and "maxpoll" was updated, the service must be restarted:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl restart chronyd.service{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "chronyd" was not running, it must be started:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl start chronyd.service

V-72273.desc: Firewalls protect computers from network attacks by blocking or limiting access to open network ports. Application firewalls limit which applications are allowed to communicate over the network.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system enabled an application firewall.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if "firewalld" is installed with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed firewalld{{{{newlineHERE}}}}firewalld-0.3.9-11.el7.noarch.rpm{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "firewalld" package is not installed, ask the System Administrator if another firewall application (such as iptables) is installed. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If an application firewall is not installed, this is a finding. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if the firewall is loaded and active with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl status firewalld{{{{newlineHERE}}}}firewalld.service - firewalld - dynamic firewall daemon{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}} Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/firewalld.service; enabled){{{{newlineHERE}}}} Active: active (running) since Tue 2014-06-17 11:14:49 CEST; 5 days ago{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "firewalld" does not show a status of "loaded" and "active", this is a finding. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the state of the firewall:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# firewall-cmd --state {{{{newlineHERE}}}}running{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "firewalld" does not show a state of "running", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Ensure the operating system's application firewall is enabled.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Install the "firewalld" package, if it is not on the system, with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum install firewalld{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Start the firewall via "systemctl" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl start firewalld

descs.check: Verify users are provided with feedback on when account accesses last occurred.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that "pam_lastlog" is used and not silent with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep pam_lastlog /etc/pam.d/postlogin{{{{newlineHERE}}}}session required pam_lastlog.so showfailed{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "pam_lastlog" is missing from "/etc/pam.d/postlogin" file, or the silent option is present, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to provide users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred by setting the required configuration options in "/etc/pam.d/postlogin". {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the following line to the top of "/etc/pam.d/postlogin":{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}session required pam_lastlog.so showfailed

descs.check: Verify there are no ".shosts" files on the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the system for the existence of these files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name '*.shosts'{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any ".shosts" files are found on the system, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Remove any found ".shosts" files from the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rm /[path]/[to]/[file]/.shosts

descs.check: Verify there are no "shosts.equiv" files on the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the system for the existence of these files with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name shosts.equiv{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If any "shosts.equiv" files are found on the system, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Remove any found "shosts.equiv" files from the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rm /[path]/[to]/[file]/shosts.equiv

descs.check: Determine whether the system is using local or DNS name resolution with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep hosts /etc/nsswitch.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}hosts: files dns{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the DNS entry is missing from the host's line in the "/etc/nsswitch.conf" file, the "/etc/resolv.conf" file must be empty.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the "/etc/resolv.conf" file is empty with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/resolv.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 0 Aug 19 08:31 resolv.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If local host authentication is being used and the "/etc/resolv.conf" file is not empty, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the DNS entry is found on the host's line of the "/etc/nsswitch.conf" file, verify the operating system is configured to use two or more name servers for DNS resolution.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Determine the name servers used by the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep nameserver /etc/resolv.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}nameserver 192.168.1.2{{{{newlineHERE}}}}nameserver 192.168.1.3{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If less than two lines are returned that are not commented out, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify that the "/etc/resolv.conf" file is immutable with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sudo lsattr /etc/resolv.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}----i----------- /etc/resolv.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file is mutable and has not been documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO), this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to use two or more name servers for DNS resolution.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Edit the "/etc/resolv.conf" file to uncomment or add the two or more "nameserver" option lines with the IP address of local authoritative name servers. If local host resolution is being performed, the "/etc/resolv.conf" file must be empty. An empty "/etc/resolv.conf" file can be created as follows:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# echo -n > /etc/resolv.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}And then make the file immutable with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# chattr +i /etc/resolv.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "/etc/resolv.conf" file must be mutable, the required configuration must be documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO) and the file must be verified by the system file integrity tool.

descs.check: Verify the system does not accept IPv4 source-routed packets.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If " net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route " is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out, or does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the accept source route variable with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned line does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0 {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}} {{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl -system

descs.check: Verify the system does not accept IPv4 source-routed packets by default.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If " net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route " is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out, or does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the accept source route variable with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned line does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route = 0 {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}} {{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl --system

descs.check: Verify the system does not respond to IPv4 ICMP echoes sent to a broadcast address.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If " net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts" is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out, or does not have a value of "1", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the "icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts" variable with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts = 1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned line does not have a value of "1", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts = 1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl --system

descs.check: Verify the system will not accept IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects' /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If " net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects " is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out, or does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the value of the "accept_redirects" variables with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects'{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned line does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the system to not accept IPv4 ICMP redirect messages by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects = 0 {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl --system

descs.check: Verify the system does not allow interfaces to perform IPv4 ICMP redirects by default.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects' /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects" is not configured in the "/etc/sysctl.conf" file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out or does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the "default send_redirects" variables with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects'{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects = 0 {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned line does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the system to not allow interfaces to perform IPv4 ICMP redirects by default. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl --system

descs.check: Verify the system does not send IPv4 ICMP redirect messages.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects' /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects" is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out or does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the "all send_redirects" variables with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects'{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned line does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the system to not allow interfaces to perform IPv4 ICMP redirects. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl --system

V-72295.desc: Network interfaces in promiscuous mode allow for the capture of all network traffic visible to the system. If unauthorized individuals can access these applications, it may allow then to collect information such as logon IDs, passwords, and key exchanges between systems.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the system is being used to perform a network troubleshooting function, the use of these tools must be documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO) and restricted to only authorized personnel.

descs.check: Verify network interfaces are not in promiscuous mode unless approved by the ISSO and documented.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the status with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ip link | grep -i promisc{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If network interfaces are found on the system in promiscuous mode and their use has not been approved by the ISSO and documented, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure network interfaces to turn off promiscuous mode unless approved by the ISSO and documented.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Set the promiscuous mode of an interface to off with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}#ip link set dev <devicename> multicast off promisc off

descs.check: Verify the system is configured to prevent unrestricted mail relaying.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Determine if "postfix" is installed with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed postfix{{{{newlineHERE}}}}postfix-2.6.6-6.el7.x86_64.rpm {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If postfix is not installed, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If postfix is installed, determine if it is configured to reject connections from unknown or untrusted networks with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# postconf -n smtpd_client_restrictions{{{{newlineHERE}}}}smtpd_client_restrictions = permit_mynetworks, reject{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "smtpd_client_restrictions" parameter contains any entries other than "permit_mynetworks" and "reject", this is a finding.
descs.fix: If "postfix" is installed, modify the "/etc/postfix/main.cf" file to restrict client connections to the local network with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# postconf -e 'smtpd_client_restrictions = permit_mynetworks,reject'

descs.check: Verify an FTP server has not been installed on the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if an FTP server has been installed with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed vsftpd{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}} vsftpd-3.0.2.el7.x86_64.rpm{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "vsftpd" is installed and is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO) as an operational requirement, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Document the "vsftpd" package with the ISSO as an operational requirement or remove it from the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum remove vsftpd

descs.check: Verify a TFTP server has not been installed on the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if a TFTP server has been installed with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed tftp-server{{{{newlineHERE}}}}tftp-server-0.49-9.el7.x86_64.rpm{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If TFTP is installed and the requirement for TFTP is not documented with the ISSO, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Remove the TFTP package from the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum remove tftp-server

descs.check: Verify remote X connections for interactive users are encrypted.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that remote X connections are encrypted with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i x11forwarding /etc/ssh/sshd_config | grep -v "^#"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}X11Forwarding yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "X11Forwarding" keyword is set to "no" or is missing, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure SSH to encrypt connections for interactive users.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "X11Forwarding" keyword and set its value to "yes" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}X11Forwarding yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl restart sshd

descs.check: Verify the TFTP daemon is configured to operate in secure mode.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if a TFTP server has been installed with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed tftp-server{{{{newlineHERE}}}}tftp-server.x86_64 x.x-x.el7 rhel-7-server-rpms{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a TFTP server is not installed, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If a TFTP server is installed, check for the server arguments with the following command: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep server_args /etc/xinetd.d/tftp{{{{newlineHERE}}}}server_args = -s /var/lib/tftpboot{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "server_args" line does not have a "-s" option and a subdirectory is not assigned, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the TFTP daemon to operate in secure mode by adding the following line to "/etc/xinetd.d/tftp" (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}server_args = -s /var/lib/tftpboot

descs.check: Verify that if the system has X Windows System installed, it is authorized.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the X11 package with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rpm -qa | grep xorg | grep server{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Ask the System Administrator if use of the X Windows System is an operational requirement.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the use of X Windows on the system is not documented with the Information System Security Officer (ISSO), this is a finding.
descs.fix: Document the requirement for an X Windows server with the ISSO or remove the related packages with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rpm -e xorg-x11-server-common

descs.check: Verify the system is not performing packet forwarding, unless the system is a router.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep net.ipv4.ip_forward /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.ip_forward = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "net.ipv4.ip_forward" is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out, or does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system does not implement IP forwarding using the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep net.ipv4.ip_forward{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.ip_forward = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If IP forwarding value is "1" and the system is hosting any application, database, or web servers, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.ip_forward = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl --system

descs.check: Verify "AUTH_GSS" is being used to authenticate NFS mounts.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}To check if the system is importing an NFS file system, look for any entries in the "/etc/fstab" file that have a file system type of "nfs" with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cat /etc/fstab | grep nfs{{{{newlineHERE}}}}192.168.21.5:/mnt/export /data1 nfs4 rw,sync ,soft,sec=krb5:krb5i:krb5p{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the system is mounting file systems via NFS and has the sec option without the "krb5:krb5i:krb5p" settings, the "sec" option has the "sys" setting, or the "sec" option is missing, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Update the "/etc/fstab" file so the option "sec" is defined for each NFS mounted file system and the "sec" option does not have the "sys" setting. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Ensure the "sec" option is defined as "krb5:krb5i:krb5p".

descs.check: Verify that a system using SNMP is not using default community strings.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if the "/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf" file exists with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}} -rw------- 1 root root 52640 Mar 12 11:08 snmpd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file does not exist, this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the file does exist, check for the default community strings with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep public /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep private /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If either of these commands returns any output, this is a finding.

If the "firewalld" package is not installed, ask the System Administrator (SA) if another firewall application (such as iptables) is installed. If an application firewall is not installed, this is a finding. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the system's access control program is configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if "firewalld" is active with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl status firewalld{{{{newlineHERE}}}}firewalld.service - firewalld - dynamic firewall daemon{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/firewalld.service; enabled){{{{newlineHERE}}}}Active: active (running) since Sun 2014-04-20 14:06:46 BST; 30s ago{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "firewalld" is active, check to see if it is configured to grant or deny access to specific hosts or services with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# firewall-cmd --get-default-zone{{{{newlineHERE}}}}public{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# firewall-cmd --list-all --zone=public{{{{newlineHERE}}}}public (active){{{{newlineHERE}}}}target: default{{{{newlineHERE}}}}icmp-block-inversion: no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}interfaces: eth0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}sources:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}services: mdns ssh{{{{newlineHERE}}}}ports:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}protocols:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}masquerade: no{{{{newlineHERE}}}}forward-ports:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}icmp-blocks:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "firewalld" is not active, determine whether "tcpwrappers" is being used by checking whether the "hosts.allow" and "hosts.deny" files are empty with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/hosts.allow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}rw-r----- 1 root root 9 Aug 2 23:13 /etc/hosts.allow{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ls -al /etc/hosts.deny{{{{newlineHERE}}}}-rw-r----- 1 root root 9 Apr 9 2007 /etc/hosts.deny{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "firewalld" and "tcpwrappers" are not installed, configured, and active, ask the SA if another access control program (such as iptables) is installed and active. Ask the SA to show that the running configuration grants or denies access to specific hosts or services.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "firewalld" is active and is not configured to grant access to specific hosts or "tcpwrappers" is not configured to grant or deny access to specific hosts, this is a finding.
descs.fix: If "firewalld" is installed and active on the system, configure rules for allowing specific services and hosts. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "firewalld" is not "active", enable "tcpwrappers" by configuring "/etc/hosts.allow" and "/etc/hosts.deny" to allow or deny access to specific hosts.

descs.check: Verify the system does not have unauthorized IP tunnels configured.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if "libreswan" is installed with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed libreswan{{{{newlineHERE}}}}libreswan.x86-64 3.20-5.el7_4{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "libreswan" is installed, check to see if the "IPsec" service is active with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# systemctl status ipsec{{{{newlineHERE}}}}ipsec.service - Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Protocol Daemon for IPsec{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/ipsec.service; disabled){{{{newlineHERE}}}}Active: inactive (dead){{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "IPsec" service is active, check to see if any tunnels are configured in "/etc/ipsec.conf" and "/etc/ipsec.d/" with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -iw conn /etc/ipsec.conf /etc/ipsec.d/*.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If there are indications that a "conn" parameter is configured for a tunnel, ask the System Administrator if the tunnel is documented with the ISSO. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "libreswan" is installed, "IPsec" is active, and an undocumented tunnel is active, this is a finding.

If IPv6 is not enabled, the key will not exist, and this is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the system does not accept IPv6 source-routed packets.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route" is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out or does not have a value of "0", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the accept source route variable with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned lines do not have a value of "0", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Set the system to the required kernel parameter, if IPv6 is enabled, by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route = 0{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# sysctl --system

V-72417.desc: Using an authentication device, such as a CAC or token that is separate from the information system, ensures that even if the information system is compromised, that compromise will not affect credentials stored on the authentication device.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Multifactor solutions that require devices separate from information systems gaining access include, for example, hardware tokens providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card and the DoD Common Access Card.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}A privileged account is defined as an information system account with authorizations of a privileged user.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement only applies to components where this is specific to the function of the device or has the concept of an organizational user (e.g., VPN, proxy capability). This does not apply to authentication for the purpose of configuring the device itself (management).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system has the packages required for multifactor authentication installed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the presence of the packages required to support multifactor authentication with the following commands:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum list installed pam_pkcs11{{{{newlineHERE}}}}pam_pkcs11-0.6.2-14.el7.noarch.rpm{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "pam_pkcs11" package is not installed, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to implement multifactor authentication by installing the required packages.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Install the pam_pkcs11 package with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# yum install pam_pkcs11

Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement only applies to components where this is specific to the function of the device or has the concept of an organizational user (e.g., VPN, proxy capability). This does not apply to authentication for the purpose of configuring the device itself (management).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the operating system implements multifactor authentication for remote access to privileged accounts via pluggable authentication modules (PAM).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check the "/etc/sssd/sssd.conf" file for the authentication services that are being used with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep services /etc/sssd/sssd.conf /etc/sssd/conf.d/*.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}services = nss, pam{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "pam" service is not present on all "services" lines, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to implement multifactor authentication for remote access to privileged accounts via pluggable authentication modules (PAM).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Modify all of the services lines in "/etc/sssd/sssd.conf" or in configuration files found under "/etc/sssd/conf.d" to include pam.

Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}This requirement only applies to components where this is specific to the function of the device or has the concept of an organizational user (e.g., VPN, proxy capability). descs.check: Verify the operating system implements certificate status checking for PKI authentication.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check to see if Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) is enabled on the system with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep cert_policy /etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf | grep -v "^#"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}cert_policy = ca, ocsp_on, signature;{{{{newlineHERE}}}}cert_policy = ca, ocsp_on, signature;{{{{newlineHERE}}}}cert_policy = ca, ocsp_on, signature;{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}There should be at least three lines returned. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "ocsp_on" is not present in all uncommented "cert_policy" lines in "/etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf", this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to do certificate status checking for PKI authentication.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Modify all of the "cert_policy" lines in "/etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf" to include "ocsp_on".

V-73155.desc: A session time-out lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not log out because of the temporary nature of the absence. Rather than relying on the user to manually lock their operating system session prior to vacating the vicinity, operating systems need to be able to identify when a user's session has idled and take action to initiate the session lock.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined and/or controlled.

descs.check: Verify the operating system prevents a user from overriding a screensaver lock after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces. {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If the system does not have GNOME installed, this requirement is Not Applicable. The screen program must be installed to lock sessions on the console.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Determine which profile the system database is using with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep system-db /etc/dconf/profile/user{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}system-db:local{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check for the lock delay setting with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example below is using the database "local" for the system, so the path is "/etc/dconf/db/local.d". This path must be modified if a database other than "local" is being used.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep -i lock-delay /etc/dconf/db/local.d/locks/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/org/gnome/desktop/screensaver/lock-delay{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the command does not return a result, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the operating system to prevent a user from overriding a screensaver lock after a 15-minute period of inactivity for graphical user interfaces.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Create a database to contain the system-wide screensaver settings (if it does not already exist) with the following command: {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: The example below is using the database "local" for the system, so if the system is using another database in "/etc/dconf/profile/user", the file should be created under the appropriate subdirectory.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/locks/session{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the setting to lock the screensaver lock delay:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}/org/gnome/desktop/screensaver/lock-delay

V-81015.desc: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Without the configuration of the "au-remote" plugin, the audisp-remote daemon will not off-load the logs from the system being audited.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the "au-remote" plugin is active on the system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep "active" /etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}active = yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "active" setting is not set to "yes", or the line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Edit the /etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf file and change the value of "active" to "yes".{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# service auditd restart

V-81017.desc: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Without the configuration of the "au-remote" plugin, the audisp-remote daemon will not off load the logs from the system being audited.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the "au-remote" plugin is configured to always off-load audit logs using the audisp-remote daemon:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# cat /etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf | grep -v "^#"{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}active = yes{{{{newlineHERE}}}}direction = out{{{{newlineHERE}}}}path = /sbin/audisp-remote{{{{newlineHERE}}}}type = always{{{{newlineHERE}}}}format = string{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "direction" setting is not set to "out", or the line is commented out, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "path" setting is not set to "/sbin/audisp-remote", or the line is commented out, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "type" setting is not set to "always", or the line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Edit the /etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf file and add or update the following values:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}direction = out{{{{newlineHERE}}}}path = /sbin/audisp-remote{{{{newlineHERE}}}}type = always{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# service auditd restart

V-81019.desc: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}When the remote buffer is full, audit logs will not be collected and sent to the central log server.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.fix: Edit the /etc/audisp/audispd.conf file and add or update the "overflow_action" option:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}overflow_action = syslog{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# service auditd restart

V-81021.desc: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}When audit logs are not labeled before they are sent to a central log server, the audit data will not be able to be analyzed and tied back to the correct system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}

descs.check: Verify the audisp daemon is configured to label all off-loaded audit logs:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep "name_format" /etc/audisp/audispd.conf{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}name_format = hostname{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the "name_format" option is not "hostname", "fqd", or "numeric", or the line is commented out, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Edit the /etc/audisp/audispd.conf file and add or update the "name_format" option:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}name_format = hostname{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# service auditd restart

descs.check: Verify the system uses a reverse-path filter for IPv4:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter /etc/sysctl.conf /etc/sysctl.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter = 1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter" is not configured in the /etc/sysctl.conf file or in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory, is commented out, or does not have a value of "1", this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the operating system implements the accept source route variable with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter{{{{newlineHERE}}}}net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter = 1{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the returned line does not have a value of "1", this is a finding.

descs.check: Ask the SA or ISSO if a host-based intrusion detection application is loaded on the system. Per OPORD 16-0080, the preferred intrusion detection system is McAfee HBSS available through the U.S. Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM).{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If another host-based intrusion detection application is in use, such as SELinux, this must be documented and approved by the local Authorizing Official.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Procedure:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Examine the system to determine if the Host Intrusion Prevention System (HIPS) is installed:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# rpm -qa | grep MFEhiplsm{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify that the McAfee HIPS module is active on the system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ps -ef | grep -i hipclient{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the MFEhiplsm package is not installed, check for another intrusion detection system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# find / -name <daemon name>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Where <daemon name> is the name of the primary application daemon to determine if the application is loaded on the system.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Determine if the application is active on the system:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# ps -ef | grep -i <daemon name>{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If the MFEhiplsm package is not installed and an alternate host-based intrusion detection application has not been documented for use, this is a finding.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If no host-based intrusion detection system is installed and running on the system, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Install and enable the latest McAfee HIPS package, available from USCYBERCOM.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Note: If the system does not support the McAfee HIPS package, install and enable a supported intrusion detection system application and document its use with the Authorizing Official.

V-94843.title: The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the x86 Ctrl-Alt-Delete key sequence is disabled in the Graphical User Interface.
V-94843.desc: A locally logged-on user who presses Ctrl-Alt-Delete, when at the console, can reboot the system. If accidentally pressed, as could happen in the case of a mixed OS environment, this can create the risk of short-term loss of availability of systems due to unintentional reboot. In the graphical environment, risk of unintentional reboot from the Ctrl-Alt-Delete sequence is reduced because the user will be prompted before any action is taken.

descs.check: Note: If the operating system does not have a graphical user interface installed, this requirement is Not Applicable.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Verify the operating system is not configured to reboot the system when Ctrl-Alt-Delete is pressed.{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Check that the ctrl-alt-del.target is masked and not active in the graphical user interface with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# grep logout /etc/dconf/db/local.d/*{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}logout=''{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}If "logout" is not set to use two single quotations, or is missing, this is a finding.
descs.fix: Configure the system to disable the Ctrl-Alt-Delete sequence for the graphical user interface with the following command:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}# touch /etc/dconf/db/local.d/00-disable-CAD {{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}Add the setting to disable the Ctrl-Alt-Delete sequence for the graphical user interface:{{{{newlineHERE}}}}{{{{newlineHERE}}}}[org/gnome/settings-daemon/plugins/media-keys]{{{{newlineHERE}}}}logout=''
